Enroute Canton-Swatow
Easter
Sunday
1936.
Dear Family:
the wing after more than two
months in Manila dur-
or rather
time wasn't taken,
correspondence.
stop at
Hongkong
went on to Macao.
that air. Chen was trying to locate
Hongkong April 6th found a
me but not knowing any Mr.
in Hongkong I assumed that he must be a Chinese reporter and so
dismissed the matter.
I arrived at the dock to catch the Macao
boat I found my old friend Ki
Chun (High School in Amherst - director
of C.N.A.C.) and his wife who had gone all the way up to the dock to
He was born in Shanghai and except for a short stay
Macao and the time he was attending high
school
and M. I.
has always lived
ancestral home is near Macao.
He told me
that he was going over on
the late boat that (Monday) after-
noon and on Wednesday would
his old home to
pray at the
his ancestors and then added characteristically
"You know a lot of
damn nonsense but we
Chinese do
that,
and it is my duty as head of
the family to visit the ancestral
graves once a year."
Interlude:
Just at that point we arrived at Swatow and as
this is a delayed-on-
account-of-weather flight and it was five o'clock we stayed there for
the night.
We went to a Chinese hostelry with the more
elegant than
warranted title of Palace Hotel.
Vaughn our pilot recommended
it in a rather negative but convincing manner by
saying that the sheets
were clean and
there were no bugs
- a statement the veracity of
I am prepared to support.
That however was
the full extent of
We dined out.
A dirty little Chinese restaurant (the best
always comes from the worst looking places and this was no excep-
There were four of us, Vaughn
the Pilot,
we could eat of
fried oysters,
(2) baked flounder,
(4) spareribs,
lobster (never
(better 11) chloer giblet
a better dinner and
was just under
for the lour of us.
strolled around
town - got lost - Hugh Chen our co-pilot,
speak the
Swatow dialect and was as
helpless as the rest of
us until he
found a policeman who
could read
characters which Hugh
wrote down - the cop pointed
the way
our hotel and by ?.m. we
in bed with a 5 A.M. call
Such was my Easter
Now we have just left Amoy where we flew
Commanding the Asiatic
who we knew in Manila.
usua
and his ancestors.
On Tuesday afternoon we got a car and drove through
which divides the Portuguese territory from
the mainland and
over a fairly good red
road some fifteen miles
to a little
village.
It seems from stories that I heard
illustrious ancestors looted
a temple and with his thus
ill gotten
gains
departed for
points
Eventually this man made a tremendous
being
sugar at Hawaii.
Ultimately he
returned to
his native heath
Chinese I suppose I should say his native rice paddy)
square himself
the Gods from whose lap he had
his nest egg,
temples and a village.
grand house for himself
with a beautiful garden.
The house
is built
along lines of the
most orthodox
of
Its
architecture, if it
deserves
the orthodox gay
nineties atrocities.
even
the
menvion
of architecture,
is
amazing
conglomeration
of
square,
rounaea
and triangular shaped

Page 2.
appendages, do-funnies and gelapies.
The windows are colonial
the glass various shades of red and blue - like the
windows at the deacons' building committee puts in a new church
some rich parishoner can be high jacked into putting out
for a stained glass job.
the woodwork was all heavily
carved in Chinese designs which clash violently with the Grand
Rapids golden oak furniture.
The rickety
chandeliers reminiscent of
better days swayed as we walked over the
dusty floors from one
deserted room to another.
Outside the garden was entirely
different.
A moon
door let us
through a high wall and there within
moss covered
enclosing
the confines of that old
an acre or more of ground was a garden
such as described by Lin Yu Tang in his "My Country and my People"
pond - walks - flowers
- little temples and many benches
in quiet spots.
garden is better maintained than the deserted
at
the
old
nearby
village love this spot to
which
retire from their
Chinese houses for peace and
they
seclusion.
Ki Chun took me
to
the Chinese house
where his father moved from Shanghai when
Ki Was five years old.
It
seems a soothsayer gave Ki's father
some advice which led to the making of
a fortune in his
early
twenties but the soothsayer also told him that he would die at
age 30.
Therefore in his 29th
year he made his brother
trustee
of
his fortune and repaired to his old home prepared to die.
However he lived
through the 30th year and then
returned to
Shanghai to resume business
activities with his brother but from
that day to this the brother's fortunes have remained merged and
no distribution has ever been made.
Ki's uncle
is still living.
When he dies
the
combined fortune will
be divided between the
two
families with Ki receiving half as the
head of and for the account
of
his family
- meaning his brothers and sisters.
on his visit to
make a present
to all his
was
expected
poor relatives and
accord-
ingly we
smuggled some
silver from Macao because A1
said those poor
people still
the
look upon paper money
"stage money".
He delivered
his old nurse
dollars - receiving
receipt, issuing no
instructions
and demanding no accounting.
Ki
said
simply - "She is loyal
to me and I shall
always
care of her
relative and
Then he
added laughingly -
relatives will be glad. to
when
and I will be a big shot."
We visited the room where Ki
got his first schooling,
examined the armory where his father's seven old rifles
ready
to repel a bandit attack,
got out a lot of old family
pictures in which Ki's grandfather's twenty-three concubines were
naturally very much in
It was a real
scenes of the old time
Chinese family life and
thoroughly enjoyed the afternoon.
We are now approaching Shanghai and I will have to go to
work.
As ever
witt
kindest regards
to you
and tars morgan -
Maroo
